questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of drooping of the right upper eyelid, constriction of the right pupil, and lack of sweating on the right side of the face. On further questioning, the patient admits to experiencing neck pain following a minor car accident a week ago. Physical examination confirms the presence of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the right side of the face. What is the most likely site of the lesion?

options.C: Pancoast tumor at the apex of the lung
options.D: Lesion of the superior orbital fissure

questions.explanation: ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating), all on the ipsilateral side. Horner's syndrome results from disruption of the sympathetic nerves supplying the eye and face. In this case, the combination of Horner's syndrome and recent neck trauma raises suspicion for internal carotid artery dissection, a known cause of Horner’s syndrome. The sympathetic fibers that innervate the eye travel along the internal carotid artery as part of the third-order neurons . A dissection of this artery can compromise these fibers, leading to the classic triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. This is an important cause of Horner’s syndrome, especially after neck trauma. Carotid dissection also carries a risk of ischemic stroke due to thromboembolism. Horner’s Syndrome: Horner’s syndrome occurs due to interruption of the sympathetic pathway to the eye and face. The sympathetic supply to the eye is a three-neuron pathway : First-order neurons originate in the hypothalamus and descend through the brainstem to the spinal cord (C8-T2) region, also known as the ciliospinal center of Budge . Second-order neurons leave the spinal cord and ascend through the sympathetic chain over the apex of the lung, synapsing in the superior cervical ganglion . Third-order neurons travel along the internal carotid artery into the cavernous sinus , then along the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to reach the eye and face. Clinical Features of Horner's Syndrome: Ptosis : Drooping of the upper eyelid due to loss of sympathetic innervation to the superior tarsal muscle (also called Muller's muscle). Miosis : Constricted pupil due to unopposed action of the parasympathetic system following loss of sympathetic input to the dilator pupillae muscle . Anhidrosis : Lack of sweating on the affected side of the face due to involvement of sympathetic fibers supplying the sweat glands. Causes of Horner's Syndrome: First-order neuron lesions : Brainstem stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord trauma (e.g., syringomyelia). Second-order neuron lesions : Pancoast tumors, thoracic aortic aneurysm, neck surgery. Third-order neuron lesions : Internal carotid artery dissection, cavernous sinus lesions. Management: In cases of suspected internal carotid artery dissection, imaging such as CT angiography or MR angiography is crucial to

questions.question: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaints of right sided weakness and difficulty speaking. His speech is slow, effortful, and fragmented with short sentences, but his comprehension is not affected. Which of the following type of aphasia is this patient suffering from?
questions.explanation: specifically the Broca’s area (located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe). Patients with Broca’s aphasia have non-fluent speech, often with grammatical errors and difficulty forming full sentences, but their comprehension remains intact. They may also have right-sided weakness, as seen in this patient. Wernicke’s Aphasia (Option A) : Wernicke’s aphasia is characterized by fluent speech with poor comprehension and the use of nonsensical or irrelevant words (word salad). People with Wernicke’s aphasia can speak in long sentences, but their speech lacks meaning. The patient in the case has non-fluent speech , which points more toward Broca's aphasia, not Wernicke's. Global Aphasia (Option C) : Global aphasia involves severe impairments in both speech production and comprehension. Patients with global aphasia have difficulty with almost all aspects of language, including speaking, understanding, reading, and writing. This patient’s preserved comprehension rules out global aphasia. Conduction Aphasia (Option D) : Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus , the pathway that connects Broca's area and Wernicke’s area. People with conduction aphasia have fluent speech but have difficulty with repetition and making corrections to their speech, often with phonemic paraphasias (incorrect sounds or words). The patient described here does not show the characteristics of fluent speech or frequent paraphasias, so this diagnosis is less likely.

questions.question: A 48-year-old male presents with acute onset weakness of the right side of the body. On examination: Right-sided complete hemiplegia Right-sided ptosis and dilated pupil Eye deviated outward and downward No sensory deficits Normal consciousness level Which type of hemiplegia is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation: motor neuron lesion affecting the corticospinal tract at any level from cortex to medulla, before its decussation. Type of Hemiplegia Location Key Features Additional Details Weber's Hemiplegia Midbrain (crus cerebri) CN III palsy + contralateral hemiplegia Ptosis, dilated pupil, outward/downward eye deviation Medial Medullary Hemiplegia (Option B ruled out) Medial medulla CN XII palsy + contralateral hemiplegia Tongue deviation to ipsilateral side Millard-Gubler Hemiplegia (Option C ruled out) Pons CN VI, VII palsy + contralateral hemiplegia Facial weakness and lateral rectus palsy Pure Motor Hemiplegia (Option D ruled out) Internal capsule Only motor deficits No cranial nerve involvement Cortical Level Hemiplegia Motor cortex (precentral gyrus) Segmental weakness, often associated with cortical signs MCA territory most commonly involved Pattern of Recovery 1. Early Phase (1-4 weeks) Initial flaccid paralysis Hypotonia Decreased/absent reflexes Poor voluntary movement 2. Intermediate Phase Development of spasticity Return of reflexes, becoming hyperactive Babinski sign appears Basic synergistic patterns emerge 3. Late Phase (Recovery Pattern) Established spasticity Sequential recovery: Proximal muscles before distal Lower limb before upper limb Extensor muscle groups before flexors Synergistic movements may persist Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 3329-3333

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and right-sided facial numbness. On examination, she has ataxia, and when asked to stick out her tongue, it deviates to the right. Additionally, she experiences nystagmus and has a diminished gag reflex. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: nystagmus, and diminished gag reflex—are characteristic of Wallenberg Syndrome (Lateral Medullary Syndrome) , which results from a lateral medullary infarction. Medial Medullary Syndrome (Option D ruled out) Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallenberg Syndrome) On side of lesion Paralysis with atrophy of one-half half the tongue: Ipsilateral twelfth nerve On side of lesion Pain, numbness, impaired sensation over one-half the face: Descending tract and nucleus fifth nerve Ataxia of limbs, falling to side of lesion: Restiform body, cerebellar hemisphere, cerebellar fibers, spinocerebellar tract Nystagmus, diplopia, oscillopsia, vertigo, nausea, vomiting: Vestibular nucleus Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating): Descending sympathetic tract Dysphagia, hoarseness, paralysis of palate, paralysis of vocal cord, diminished gag reflex: Issuing fibers ninth and tenth nerves Loss of taste: Nucleus and tractus solitarius Numbness of ipsilateral arm, trunk, or leg: Cuneate and gracile nuclei Weakness of lower face: Genuflected upper motor neuron fibers to ipsilateral facial nucleus On side opposite lesion Paralysis of arm and leg, sparing face; impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense over one-half the body: Contralateral pyramidal tract and medial lemniscus On side opposite lesion Impaired pain and thermal sense over half the body, sometimes face: Spinothalamic tract Weber Syndrome (Option A) is caused by a ventral midbrain infarction, leading to contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy, but it does not present with the ataxia or dysphagia seen in this case. Foville Syndrome (Option C) involves a pontine infarction, resulting in contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral abducens palsy, along with facial sensory deficits, but lacks the ataxia and swallowing difficulties seen here. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3329

questions.question: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he collapsed at his home, and the neurologist suspects a medullary stroke after a thorough evaluation. Which of the following is NOT a feature of a medullary stroke?

options.D: Ipsilateral facial pain and loss of temperature sensation

questions.explanation: cortex, while medullary strokes primarily result in ipsilateral deficits, including facial pain and dysphagia. Medullary stroke Medullary strokes involve infarctions in the medulla oblongata, which is critical for various autonomic, sensory, and motor functions. The medulla is supplied by paramedian bulbar arteries (from vertebral arteries and anterior spinal artery) for the medial medulla, and lateral bulbar arteries (from vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery) for the lateral medulla. Clinical Features: Cardiovascular-Respiratory Centers : Disruption causes unstable blood pressure and irregular breathing. (Option A ruled out) Nucleus of the Solitary Tract (NTS) : Impairment leads to altered baroreflex, respiratory issues, and loss of taste. Area Postrema : Damage causes nausea, vomiting, and reduced gag reflex. Spinal Trigeminal Nucleus : Lesion results in ipsilateral facial pain and loss of temperature/pain sensation. (Option D ruled out) Inferior Olivary Nucleus : Affected motor coordination leads to ataxia and tremors. Pyramidal Decussation : Damage causes contralateral muscle weakness or paralysis. Cuneate and Gracile Nuclei : Lesion causes loss of proprioception and fine touch on the ipsilateral side. Medial Lemniscus : Impairment leads to contralateral loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch. Spinothalamic Tract : Damage results in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Cranial Nerves IX, X, XI, XII : Affected nerves cause dysphagia, dysarthria, tongue deviation, and hoarseness. (Option B ruled out) Reference: Neuroanatomy, Medulla Oblongata - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A 58-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after suddenly collapsing at home. Upon examination, he is fully conscious and aware of his surroundings but is unable to move any limbs or speak. He shows no signs of respiratory distress but struggles with swallowing and cannot perform any voluntary movements, except for blinking and vertical eye movements. What condition is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: ability to perform vertical eye movements and blinking—is characteristic of Locked-in Syndrome. This condition results from damage in the brainstem, particularly the anterior pons, affecting motor control while sparing cognitive functions. Locked-in Syndrome (Pseudocoma) Locked-in syndrome (LIS) is a condition characterized by quadriplegia, bulbar palsy, and sensory loss due to damage in the brain stem, often the anterior pons. Causes include vascular lesions, tumors, infections, trauma, and demyelinating disorders. Lesions affect the ventral pons or caudal ventral midbrain while sparing the cerebrum. Damage to cranial nerve nuclei leads to loss of voluntary muscle control. Corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts are affected, impacting motor and sensory functions. The reticular activating system, responsible for wakefulness, remains intact. Clinical Features: Functions lost: Paralysis of limbs and torso. Bulbar palsy leading to anarthria and dysphagia. Difficulty with breathing, potential apnea, hyperpnea, ataxia. Dizziness, Vertigo Functions retained: Consciousness, orientation and language comprehension. Hearing and ability to perform vertical eye movements and blinking. Parinaud Syndrome (Option A) results from lesions in the midbrain, often affecting the vertical gaze. Patients may have difficulties with eye movement but typically retain motor function and consciousness, which does not match the clinical presentation in the scenario. Claude Syndrome (Option B) is caused by lesions in the midbrain that affect the oculomotor nerve and the red nucleus, leading to oculomotor palsy and ataxia. Patients may have motor and sensory deficits, but unlike Locked-in Syndrome, they do not retain the ability to perform vertical eye movements. Raymond Syndrome (Option C) results from lesions affecting the corticospinal and abducens pathways in the pons, leading to contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy. While it shares some similarities, it does not present with the preserved consciousness and eye movement found in Locked-in Syndrome. Reference: Locked-in Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf www.ninds.nih.gov/health-information/disorders/locked-syndrome

questions.question: A 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing sudden weakness on the left side of his body. On examination, he exhibits right-sided facial droop and difficulty moving his right eye laterally. He has also lost the ability to feel pain and temperature on the right side of his body. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: abducens palsy—are characteristic of Millard-Gubler Syndrome, which results from a ventro-caudal pontine infarction. This aligns with the specific deficits observed in the clinical scenario. Pontine Stroke Syndrome Ventro-caudal Pontine Infarction -Paramedian perforating arteries arising from the basilar artery. Contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract). Ipsilateral abducens palsy (abducens nerve). Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy (facial nerve). Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (lateral spinothalamic tract). Millard-Gubler Syndrome : Contralateral hemiparesis, ipsilateral abducens, and facial nerve palsy. Foville Syndrome : Same as Millard-Gubler with additional conjugate gaze palsy. (Option A ruled out) Raymond Syndrome : Contralateral hemiparesis with ipsilateral abducens palsy, no facial nerve involvement. (Option D ruled out) Mid-pontine Base Infarction -Paramedian arteries or short circumferential arteries, both arising from the basilar artery. Ipsilateral ataxia (pontine nuclei). Ipsilateral facial sensorimotor weakness (trigeminal nerve). Contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract). Pure Motor Hemiparesis : Isolated contralateral motor weakness due to corticospinal tract infarct. Ataxic Hemiparesis : Ipsilateral ataxia with contralateral motor weakness. Dysarthria-Clumsy Hand Syndrome : Dysarthria, dysphagia, impaired hand dexterity, and weakness. (Option C ruled out) Tegmental Pontine Syndrome -Rostral Pontine Syndrome: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery or superior cerebellar artery. -Caudal Pontine Syndrome: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery or short circumferential arteries. Ipsilateral facial sensory disturbance (trigeminal nucleus). Ipsilateral masticator paralysis (trigeminal motor nucleus). Impaired blinking (tectospinal tract). Contralateral hemisensory loss (medial lemniscus and lateral spinothalamic tract). Ipsilateral hemiataxia (superior cerebellar peduncle). Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3330-3332 Pontine Infarction - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with severe burning pain on the left side of his body three months after having a stroke. He describes the pain as constant and stabbing, with episodes of intense shooting pain lasting several minutes. Physical examination reveals hyperalgesia and allodynia in the affected areas, with abnormal temperature sensation. MRI shows a lesion in the ventroposterolateral thalamus. Which of the following best describes this condition?

options.A: Complex regional pain syndrome with peripheral nerve involvement
options.B: Dejerine Roussy syndrome with central thalamic pain

questions.explanation: presents with the classic triad of features that define Dejerine Roussy syndrome: Timing: Pain develops after stroke (in this case, 3 months post-stroke) Location: Lesion in ventroposterolateral thalamus confirmed by MRI Pain characteristics: Combination of all three pain components described in Dejerine Roussy syndrome- Constant burning pain, intermittent shooting pain, evoked pain (hyperalgesia and allodynia) Dejerine Roussy Syndrome Pain Components Spontaneous constant pain (burning, aching, freezing) Spontaneous intermittent pain (shooting, lancinating) Evoked pain (hyperalgesia, allodynia) Pain Characteristics Sharp, burning, stabbing quality Affects areas corresponding to stroke May be immediate or delayed up to several months Sensory Findings Abnormal pain/temperature sensation (90% cases) Hyperalgesia Allodynia Variable touch/vibration changes Anatomical Location Primarily: Ventroposterolateral thalamus Can occur with lesions anywhere along spinothalamic tract Complex regional pain syndrome with peripheral nerve involvement (Option A) is incorrect because complex regional pain syndrome is a peripheral nerve condition typically following trauma or surgery. Trigeminal neuralgia with facial pain (Option C) is incorrect because trigeminal neuralgia specifically affects the distribution of the trigeminal nerve with different pain characteristics. Post-herpetic neuralgia with dermatomal distribution (Option D) is incorrect because post-herpetic neuralgia follows herpes zoster infection and has a specific dermatomal distribution. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine 21st Edition Page 3328 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519047/

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive difficulty looking upward and complains of double vision. On examination, he demonstrates impaired upward gaze, jerky convergence movements of both eyes on attempted upward gaze, and pupils that constrict poorly to light but constrict well with near vision. He has adopted a chin-up position to compensate. MRI reveals a mass in the pineal region. Which of the following best characterizes this condition and its classic triad?

options.A: Paralysis of downward gaze, convergence weakness, and pineal mass
options.B: Paralysis of upward gaze, convergence-retraction nystagmus, and pupillary light-near dissociation
options.C: Paralysis of lateral gaze, retraction nystagmus, and normal pupils
options.D: Complete ophthalmoplegia, dilated pupils, and pineal calcification

questions.explanation: light-near dissociation is typically caused by a mass in the pineal region compressing the dorsal midbrain . The classic triad includes paralysis of upward gaze , convergence-retraction nystagmus (jerky eye movements on attempted up gaze), and pupillary light-near dissociation (pupils poorly reactive to light but responsive to near stimuli). This results from compression of structures like the superior colliculi and pretectal area , which are involved in vertical gaze and pupillary light reflexes. The chin-up posture is a compensatory mechanism for the vertical gaze palsy. Parinaud Syndrome Classic Triad 1. Impaired upward gaze (upgaze palsy) 2. Convergence-retraction nystagmus 3. Pupillary light-near dissociation Common Symptoms - Difficulty looking up - Diplopia (65% of patients) - Blurred near vision - Oscillopsia - Compensatory chin-up position Additional Signs - Collier's sign (lid retraction) in 40% - "Setting sun" sign - Loss of convergence (<25% of patients) Common Causes - Pineal tumors (most common in young) - Midbrain infarction - Hydrocephalus - Multiple sclerosis - Hemorrhage - Infections (toxoplasmosis) Anatomical Location Dorsal midbrain/pretectal area at level of superior colliculus Reference: Parinaud Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A 62-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of left-sided drooping eyelid and difficulty coordinating movements of his right arm and leg. On examination, he has left-sided ptosis, dilated left pupil, and the left eye is "down and out." He demonstrates significant right-sided ataxia but has normal strength in all extremities. Which of the following conditions represent the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation: tegmentum affecting the oculomotor nerve (causing ipsilateral third nerve palsy: ptosis, "down and out" eye, dilated pupil) and the red nucleus or superior cerebellar peduncle , leading to contralateral ataxia . Claude Syndrome Anatomical Location Midbrain (Red Nucleus Region) Structures Affected - Oculomotor nerve (CN III) - Red nucleus - Dentatothalamic tract Ipsilateral Findings (CN III) - Ptosis - Dilated pupil - "Down and out" eye position - Diplopia Contralateral Findings - Cerebellar ataxia - Limb incoordination - No hemiparesis (key distinguishing feature) - Intention tremor Key Distinguishing Features - No hemiparesis (unlike Weber) - No choreiform movements (unlike Benedikt) - Contralateral ataxia (unlike Nothnagel) Vascular Supply Paramedian branches of posterior cerebral artery Common Causes - Stroke (most common) - Hemorrhage - Tumor - Multiple sclerosis Weber syndrome (Option A): It involves the cerebral peduncle and oculomotor nerve, causing ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiparesis (not ataxia), due to involvement of descending motor pathways. Benedikt syndrome (Option C) : Combines features of both Claude and Weber syndromes , with oculomotor nerve palsy , contralateral ataxia , and involuntary movements (e.g., tremors), due to more extensive midbrain involvement including the red nucleus and corticospinal tract. Nothnagel syndrome (Option D): It involves the superior cerebellar peduncle and causes ataxia with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy , but is less well-defined and rare, and doesn't typically explain all the findings as well as Claude syndrome. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine 21st Edition Page 3328 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560896/

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with double vision and difficulty maintaining balance while walking. On examination, she has drooping of the right eyelid, a dilated right pupil, and significant unsteadiness with right-sided limb ataxia. Unlike other midbrain syndromes, she has no weakness in her extremities. Which of the following are the structures affected?

options.A: Superior cerebellar peduncle and CN III

questions.explanation: characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor (CN III) palsy —manifesting as ptosis, a dilated pupil, and a "down and out" eye—along with ipsilateral limb ataxia due to involvement of the superior cerebellar peduncle , which carries output from the cerebellum. The absence of motor weakness distinguishes Nothnagel syndrome from other midbrain syndromes. Nothnagel Syndrome Anatomical Location Dorsal Midbrain (Quadrigeminal Plate) Structures Affected - Oculomotor nerve (CN III) - Superior cerebellar peduncle Ipsilateral Findings - CN III palsy (ptosis, dilated pupil, eye deviation) - Cerebellar ataxia - Limb incoordination - Gait disturbance Key Distinguishing Features - No contralateral hemiparesis (unlike Weber) - No tremors (unlike Benedikt) - Often bilateral - Commonly associated with tumors Common Causes - Pineal region tumors - Quadrigeminal plate tumors - Vascular lesions - Multiple sclerosis Clinical Significance - Often presents as neuro-ophthalmological emergency - May be first sign of pineal region tumor - Usually requires neuroimaging for diagnosis Cerebral peduncle and CN III (Option B) describe Weber syndrome , which presents with CN III palsy and contralateral hemiparesis , due to damage to descending corticospinal fibers. Red nucleus and CN III (Options C & D) are features of Benedikt syndrome , which causes CN III palsy along with contralateral ataxia and involuntary movements (like tremor or chorea) from red nucleus involvement. Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560896/

questions.question: A 58-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and left-sided drooping of the eyelid. On examination, he has left-sided ptosis, a dilated left pupil that doesn't react to light, and the left eye is "down and out." He also has right-sided hemiparesis affecting his face, arm, and leg. Which of the following best describes this syndrome and its anatomical location?

options.A: Claude syndrome - Red nucleus and CN III
options.B: Weber syndrome - Cerebral peduncle and CN III
options.C: Benedict syndrome - Red nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle
options.D: Millard-Gubler syndrome - Ventral pons affecting CN VI and VII

questions.explanation: by a lesion affecting the cerebral peduncle and the oculomotor nerve (CN III) . Damage to CN III results in ipsilateral oculomotor palsy - manifesting as ptosis , a dilated pupil , and the eye positioned "down and out" . Simultaneously, involvement of the cerebral peduncle , which contains the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts , leads to contralateral hemiparesis of the face, arm, and leg . This combination of cranial nerve III palsy on one side and motor weakness on the opposite side defines Weber syndrome , with the lesion located in the ventral midbrain . Weber Syndrome Characteristic Description Anatomical Location Ventral Midbrain (Cerebral Peduncle) Structures Affected - Oculomotor nerve (CN III) - Cerebral peduncle (corticospinal tract) Ipsilateral Findings (CN III) - Ptosis (drooping eyelid) - Dilated pupil (parasympathetic) - "Down and out" eye position - Impaired medial, upward, and downward gaze Contralateral Findings - Hemiparesis/hemiplegia (face, arm, leg) - Spastic paralysis - Hyperreflexia - Babinski sign Vascular Supply Paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery Common Causes - Stroke (most common) - Tumor - Hemorrhage - Multiple sclerosis Claude syndrome - Red nucleus and CN III (Option A): Involves the red nucleus and CN III, causing oculomotor nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia rather than hemiparesis. Benedict syndrome - Red nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle (Option C): Affects the red nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle, leading to oculomotor nerve palsy along with contralateral ataxia and tremor, not pure hemiparesis. Millard-Gubler syndrome - Ventral pons affecting CN VI and VII (Option D): Involves the ventral pons with CN VI and VII, leading to contralateral hemiparesis but does not affect CN III or cause a "down and out" eye. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine 21st Edition Page 3328 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560896/

questions.question: A 54-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of double vision, left-sided weakness, and difficulty moving his right eye. On examination, the patient has a right-sided ptosis, a dilated pupil that does not react to light, and an outward deviation of the right eye. The left side of his body shows weakness with hyperreflexia. MRI reveals an ischemic lesion in the midbrain. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?

options.A: Trochlear nerve nucleus and Crus cerebri
options.B: Oculomotor nerve nucleus and Crus cerebri

questions.explanation: involves a lesion in the midbrain affecting both the oculomotor nerve and the corticospinal tract in the crus cerebri. Arteries involved are paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery. Structures Involved in a Midbrain Stroke: Oculomotor Nerve Nucleus (Cranial Nerve III): Function: Controls most of the eye movements, pupillary constriction, and eyelid elevation (levator palpebrae superioris). Clinical Findings: Damage to the oculomotor nerve leads to ptosis , a dilated pupil (mydriasis) , and an eye that is deviated outward and downward (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles). Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): Function: Innervates the superior oblique muscle, which helps in depression and intorsion of the eye. Clinical Findings: A lesion of the trochlear nerve causes vertical diplopia - difficulty looking downwards and inwards, noticed while reading or descending stairs. Trochlear nerve damage would not explain the ptosis or mydriasis seen in this patient (Option A ruled out) . Substantia Nigra: Function: Part of the basal ganglia, it plays a crucial role in motor control and coordination, with loss of dopamine-producing neurons here leading to Parkinsonism . Clinical Findings: Midbrain strokes affecting the substantia nigra can result in motor deficits, tremors, and bradykinesia, similar to Parkinson's disease. The patient's main issues involve cranial nerve III and motor weakness, not Parkinsonism features (Option C ruled out). Crus Cerebri (Corticospinal Tracts): Function: Contains descending fibers of the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, responsible for voluntary motor control. Clinical Findings: Damage here leads to contralateral hemiparesis due to involvement of the corticospinal tract. In Weber syndrome, the lesion commonly affects both the oculomotor nerve and the crus cerebri. While the crus cerebri is affected in this case, it alone does not account for the cranial nerve signs (Option D ruled out). Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559158/ Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 3328

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness, inability to speak, and unawareness of his surroundings. On examination, he has complete right-sided hemiplegia, and global aphasia, and is neglecting the right side of his visual field. Non-contrast CT of the brain shows a hypodense area involving the left middle cerebral artery territory. What is the most likely type of stroke?
questions.explanation: involving large vessels, usually the internal carotid artery or the proximal middle cerebral artery (MCA) . TACS presents with a triad of features: Hemiplegia/hemiparesis affects at least two areas of the body (face, arm, or leg) on one side. Cortical dysfunction , which includes either global aphasia (when the dominant hemisphere is affected) or neglect (when the non-dominant hemisphere is involved). Homonymous hemianopia , indicating a visual field deficit. This patient has all three cardinal features of TACS, making it the most likely diagnosis. Lacunar Stroke (Option A) : Involves small perforating arteries and affects the subcortical structures such as the basal ganglia, internal capsule, thalamus, and pons. Lacunar strokes do not involve cortical symptoms like aphasia or visual field defects, as seen in this patient. They present with "pure motor," "pure sensory," or ataxic hemiparesis syndromes, but cortical signs are absent, ruling this out. Posterior Circulation Stroke (Option B) : Strokes in the posterior circulation involve the vertebrobasilar system, including the brainstem, cerebellum, and occipital lobes. Symptoms typically include dizziness, ataxia, visual disturbances like cortical blindness, and cranial nerve abnormalities, which do not match this patient’s presentation of hemiplegia, aphasia, and neglect. Partial Anterior Circulation Stroke (PACS) (Option C) : PACS affects only part of the anterior circulation, usually just the MCA or ACA territory. PACS is differentiated from TACS by the fact that not all three key features (hemiplegia, cortical dysfunction, and visual field defect) are present. In PACS, one or two features of TACS may be seen, but the full triad is absent. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 3325-3328 https://radiopaedia.org/articles/anterior-circulation-infarction

questions.question: A 68-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and aphasia. CT angiography reveals an occlusion in one of the arteries. Which of the following best describes the location of this occlusion? Correct Answer: Unknown Explanation: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is divided into four segments: M1, M2, M3, and M4. The M1 segment, also known as the horizontal or sphenoidal segment , is the proximal portion of the MCA that extends from its origin at the internal carotid artery bifurcation to its bifurcation or trifurcation into the M2 segments. An occlusion in this segment would likely result in the symptoms described (right-sided weakness and aphasia), as it supplies a large portion of the lateral cerebral cortex, including motor and language areas . Internal Carotid Artery, Anterior Cerebral Artery, Middle Cerebral Artery Vessel Location/Course Key Areas Supplied Clinical Features When Occluded Internal Carotid Artery (ICA) Ascends through neck, enters skull via carotid canal Gives rise to MCA and ACA Large territory infarcts affecting both MCA and ACA distributions Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) (Option D) Courses anteriorly and curves around corpus callosum Medial surface of cerebral hemisphere, anterior 3/4 of corpus callosum Contralateral leg weakness, behavioral changes MCA - M1 Segment Horizontal course from ICA bifurcation to MCA bifurcation Lenticulostriate arteries to basal ganglia Contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (if dominant hemisphere) MCA - M2 Segment (Option C) Insular segment in Sylvian fissure

A 62-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and difficulty comprehending language. A CT scan reveals an ischemic stroke. The stroke likely involves which of the following vessels?
questions.explanation: language (receptive aphasia) strongly suggest involvement of the left MCA (assuming left hemisphere dominance), which supplies Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas. Thus, the MCA is the vessel most likely involved in this patient’s presentation. Blood Supply of the Brain: The brain is primarily supplied by two systems: the anterior circulation from the internal carotid arteries and the posterior circulation from the vertebral arteries . These arteries anastomose to form the Circle of Willis , providing collateral circulation between the anterior and posterior blood supplies 1. Internal Carotid Artery (ICA) Branches : Ophthalmic artery : Supplies the eye and orbital structures. Posterior communicating artery (PCoA) : Connects the internal carotid artery with the posterior cerebral artery. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) : Supplies medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes. Middle cerebral artery (MCA) : The largest branch, supplies the lateral aspect of the brain. Internal carotid artery occlusion can cause ischemia in MCA or ACA territory or a watershed (border zone) infarct between these areas. 2. Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) Supply : Medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes, including the superior portion of the motor and sensory cortices (leg area). ACA Stroke : (Option A) Contralateral weakness and sensory loss, primarily affecting the lower limb (leg > arm). Frontal lobe symptoms, including abulia (lack of initiative) and personality changes. Urinary incontinence due to damage to the medial frontal lobes. 3. Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Supply : Lateral surface of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes; basal ganglia; and internal capsule. MCA Stroke : (Option B) Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss (face and arm > leg). Aphasia if the dominant hemisphere (usually left) is affected. Hemineglect if the non-dominant hemisphere is involved. Homonymous hemianopia due to optic radiation involvement. 4. Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) Supply : Occipital lobe (visual cortex), inferior temporal lobe, thalamus, and parts of the midbrain. PCA Stroke : (Option C) Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes). Thalamic pain syndrome (Dejerine-Roussy syndrome) if the thalamus is involved, leading to contralateral sensory loss followed by chronic pain. Memory disturbances if the temporal lobe is affected. 5. Vertebral Arteries Branches : Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) : Supplies the cerebellum and lateral medulla. PICA Stroke : Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome): Causes ipsilateral facial numbness, contralateral body numbness, ataxia, vertigo, and dysphagia. 6. Basilar Artery Supply : Pons, midbrain, occipital lobes, and cerebellum. Branches : Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) : Supplies the cerebellum and parts of the brainstem. Superior cerebellar artery (SCA) : Supplies the superior cerebellum and parts of the midbrain. Posterior cerebral arteries (PCA) : Terminal branches that supply the occipital lobe. Basilar Artery Stroke : (Option D) Locked-in syndrome : Quadriplegia with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements due to damage to the pons. Cranial nerve palsies (especially those involving eye movements like the oculomotor nerve). Ataxia , vertigo, and dysarthria due to

questions.question: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department after suddenly losing vision in the left visual field of both eyes. He denies any headache, weakness, or sensory deficits. On examination, his visual acuity is intact, but he has left homonymous hemianopia. There is no evidence of motor or sensory loss. Where is the most likely site of the stroke?
questions.explanation: pathway involves the optic nerves, chiasm, and radiations that project to the occipital lobe. The primary visual cortex in this lobe receives and interprets visual information from the contralateral visual field, meaning a lesion in the right occipital lobe will affect the left visual field of both eyes and vice versa. In this patient, the presence of left homonymous hemianopia suggests damage to the visual pathways beyond the optic chiasm, specifically affecting the right occipital lobe. Visual field loss that affects the same side of both eyes (homonymous hemianopia) is a hallmark of occipital lobe stroke, contralateral to the side of the visual field defect . Left homonymous hemianopia in Right occipital lobe disease homonymous hemianopia" data-author="Mudsk" data-hash="9348" data-license="CC0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Left-homonymous-hemianopia.svg" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ycbLJm1wlLMB4rhVasWE1744368731.png" /> Localization of Stroke in the Occipital Lobe: Effects of Unilateral Occipital Lobe Disease (Right or Left): Contralateral homonymous hemianopia : This is a characteristic feature of an occipital lobe lesion. The visual field loss is congruent , meaning it affects the same portion of the visual field in both eyes. It may involve the central field ( splitting the macula ) or peripheral fields. Homonymous hemiachromatopsia : Loss of color vision in the same half of the visual field. Irritative lesions can lead to elementary visual hallucinations , such as flashes of light or geometric shapes. Effects of Right Occipital Lobe Disease: Visual illusions and hallucinations : More extensive lesions in the right occipital lobe may produce complex visual disturbances , such as visual illusions (distorted perception of objects) and hallucinations (seeing things that are not present). Loss of topographic memory and visual orientation : Patients may have difficulty recognizing familiar places or navigating through space, affecting their ability to understand spatial relationships. Effects of Left Occipital Lobe Disease: In addition to the visual field deficits described above, Lesion of the splenium of the corpus callosum : This can cause alexia without agraphia , where the patient loses the ability to read while maintaining the ability to write. Object agnosia : The inability to recognize or identify objects despite having normal vision. Effects of Bilateral Occipital Lobe Disease: Cortical blindness : The patient is unable to see, but the pupils remain reactive to light. Anton’s syndrome : A rare condition where the patient is unaware of their blindness and may confabulate about their visual experiences. Prosopagnosia : The inability to recognize familiar faces, even though basic vision is preserved. Simultanagnosia : The inability to synthesize multiple elements of a visual scene, making it difficult to read more than one word or letter at a time. Balint’s syndrome : A combination of symptoms affecting visual attention and coordination,

questions.question: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after her family noticed significant changes in her behavior and difficulty speaking. Upon examination, she displays weakness on the right side of her body and struggles to form coherent sentences, often speaking in short, fragmented phrases. The family also reports that she has become more irritable and has difficulty managing her daily tasks. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: (indicative of Broca’s aphasia), and behavioral changes such as irritability—are characteristic of a frontal lobe stroke. The frontal lobe is crucial for language, executive function, and emotional regulation, which aligns with the impairments observed in this case. Frontal Lobe Stroke: Obstruction of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA). Motor impairments: Hemiparesis/Hemiplegia: Weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body. Ataxia: Uncoordinated movement, affecting limbs, gait, speech, and swallowing. Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing. Speech and language: Aphasia: Especially common in left frontal lobe stroke (Broca’s area), affecting speech and language formation. Cognitive deficits: Executive dysfunction: Impaired decision-making, planning, attention, and multitasking. Vascular dementia: Memory loss, poor impulse control, and behavioral changes. Behavior and personality changes: Emotional dysregulation: Irritability, impulsiveness, apathy, anxiety, or decreased motivation. Incontinence: Loss of bladder and bowel control. Impaired spatial reasoning: Difficulty with spatial awareness and navigation. Each hemisphere affects the opposite side of the body, with left frontal lobe strokes affecting speech more, and right frontal lobe strokes often leading to spatial reasoning impairments. Right Temporal Lobe Stroke (Option A) affects auditory processing and memory, leading to difficulties with sound recognition and visual memory, but it would not typically cause significant speech impairments or changes in behavior. Occipital Lobe Stroke (Option C) primarily results in visual disturbances, such as blurred vision or visual field loss, and would not account for the cognitive and speech issues present in this scenario. Left Parietal Lobe Stroke (Option D) can cause issues with language and spatial awareness but does not typically lead to the emotional and executive function deficits observed in this patient. Reference: www.flintrehab.com/frontal-lobe-stroke/

questions.question: A 55-year-old right-handed man presents to the emergency department after his partner noticed he has been struggling to communicate effectively. He speaks in long sentences but often uses nonsensical words and seems unaware of his errors. Additionally, he has difficulty remembering recent conversations and frequently confuses familiar faces. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: it the most likely site of the stroke in this case. The patient's symptoms—fluent speech with nonsensical word use (indicative of Wernicke’s aphasia), difficulty recalling recent conversations, and trouble recognizing faces—are characteristic of a left temporal lobe stroke. Features of Left Temporal Lobe Stroke Features of Right Temporal Lobe Stroke Impaired language and memory: Difficulty with spoken language and remembering verbal information. Fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia: Fluent speech with incorrect words, affecting language comprehension. Poor visual memory and spatial awareness: Difficulty recognizing visual patterns and spatial information. Prosopagnosia : Inability to recognize faces, including familiar ones. (Option A ruled out) General Features of Temporal Lobe Stroke Poor memory: Difficulty recalling past memories and learning new information. Prosopagnosia: Trouble recognizing faces and objects. Fluent aphasia: Specifically in left-sided strokes, affecting speech fluency but with incorrect word use. Visual perception difficulties: Challenges with interpreting the visual field and surroundings. Trouble processing sound: Inability to differentiate or process sounds correctly. Emotional and behavioral changes: Varying behaviors due to damage to the amygdala, such as aggression, passiveness, or difficulty interpreting facial cues. Right Parietal Lobe Stroke (Option C) usually results in spatial awareness issues, such as hemineglect, poor navigation skills, and difficulty recognizing the left side of the body or surroundings. The symptoms presented in the scenario—such as fluent speech with incorrect word use and memory difficulties—are not consistent with right parietal lobe dysfunction. Frontal Lobe Stroke (Option D) often leads to changes in personality, impaired executive function, and difficulties with movement (e.g., weakness or apraxia). While a frontal lobe stroke can affect speech (particularly expressive aphasia), it does not typically result in fluent aphasia or nonsensical speech as described in the scenario. The patient’s symptoms align more closely with a left temporal lobe stroke. Reference: www.flintrehab.com/temporal-lobe-stroke/

questions.question: A 62-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the hospital after her husband noticed she was having trouble writing and appeared confused about her left and right sides. Upon examination, she struggles to recognize familiar objects and is unable to perform simple calculations. Her speech is intact, but she has difficulty repeating phrases. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: confusion, and agnosia. As the dominant hemisphere for a right-handed individual, the left parietal lobe is associated with language processing and numerical abilities, which aligns with her symptoms. Features of Left Parietal Lobe Stroke (Dominant) Features of Right Parietal Lobe Stroke (Non-Dominant) Agnosia : Difficulty recognizing objects, people, or sounds. Right-left confusion : Poor differentiation between right and left sides. Agraphia : Difficulty with writing due to motor or memory issues. Acalculia : Inability to process numbers and perform simple math. Aphasia : Difficulty with speech, often conduction aphasia (speech repetition issues). Gerstmann’s Syndrome : Involves Angular gyrus - Brodmann area 39 Triad of agnosia, agraphia, and acalculia. Hemineglect : Decreased awareness of the left side of the body or surroundings. (Option D ruled out) Poor spatial awareness : Difficulty navigating due to spatial perception issues. Impaired sense of direction and visual memory : Difficulty navigating environments. Anosognosia : Inability to perceive or acknowledge stroke-related deficits. Proprioception dysfunction : Difficulty sensing body parts in space, affecting balance and coordination. Both lobes can also be affected, leading to further memory changes or Balint’s Syndrome (visual processing and gaze issues). Right Temporal Lobe Stroke (Option A) primarily affects auditory processing and memory. Patients may experience difficulties with recognizing familiar sounds or faces and may have issues with visual memory. The symptoms described in the scenario, such as writing difficulties and right-left confusion, do not align with a right temporal lobe stroke. Left Temporal Lobe Stroke (Option B) can result in language deficits, including difficulty with understanding spoken language and expressive aphasia. While the patient has some speech difficulties, the presence of agnosia, agraphia, and right-left confusion points more specifically to left parietal lobe involvement rather than isolated temporal lobe damage. Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10579499/ www.flintrehab.com/parietal-lobe-stroke/

questions.question: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden right-sided weakness and difficulty coordinating his movements. He also reports an altered sensation on the right side. His medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. Upon examination, he shows reduced strength in his right arm and leg. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: characteristic of a lacunar stroke, which affects subcortical structures. The presentation aligns with pure motor hemiparesis or ataxic hemiparesis, commonly seen in lacunar strokes, especially given his background of hypertension and diabetes. Cortical strokes: Affects the cerebral cortical areas (Lobes). Symptoms include aphasia, neglect, and hemianopia. Cortical strokes often begin suddenly and worsen over time. Frontal Lobe Stroke: Impaired memory, speech difficulties, personality changes, movement issues. (Option A ruled out) Temporal Lobe Stroke: Short-term memory loss, hearing problems, aphasia (communication disorder). (Option B ruled out) Parietal Lobe Stroke: Paresthesia (numbness and tingling), aphasia. Occipital Lobe Stroke: Visual changes, such as blurriness, visual hallucinations, or cortical blindness. (Option C ruled out) Brainstem strokes: Affect the brainstem areas- midbrain, pons, and medulla. Symptoms include muscle weakness, hearing and vision problems, sensory changes, balance problems, and difficulty breathing, chewing, swallowing, and speaking. Lacunar strokes: Affect the subcortical deep brain structures, including the thalamus, basal ganglia, pons, and white matter of the internal capsule. Symptoms include weakness and clumsiness on one side of the body, impaired coordination on one side of the body, and changes in sensations like temperature, touch, or taste. Lacunar stroke presents in Pure motor hemiparesis, Ataxic-hemiparesis, Pure sensory, Dysarthria-clumsy hand and Sensory-motor Lacunar strokes often worsen in small steps over the initial hours. Reference: Lacunar Stroke - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf Brainstem Stroke - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf. www.healthline.com/health/stroke-types#cortical-strokes www.flintrehab.com/areas-of-the-brain-affected-by-stroke/

questions.question: A 72-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking which started 2 hours ago. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a prior TIA. His BP is 180/110 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head rules out hemorrhagic stroke. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient? thrombolytic therapy.

options.B: Start intravenous heparin for anticoagulation therapy.
options.C: Initiate blood pressure management to lower the BP to <160/90 mmHg before considering
options.D: Begin treatment with antipyretics and surface cooling to manage fever.

questions.explanation: difficulty speaking. The CT scan ruling out hemorrhagic stroke further confirms the diagnosis. Administering intravenous Alteplase immediately is appropriate as the patient presents with signs of an ischemic stroke and is within the treatment window for intravenous thrombolysis (within 3-4.5 hours). Since the CT scan has ruled out hemorrhagic stroke, administering rtPA is crucial for improving outcomes by restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain. Management of Ischemic Stroke Optimize Cerebral Perfusion: Goal: Preserve the ischemic penumbra. Blood Pressure (BP) Management: Reduce BP if >220/120 mmHg, or >185/110 mmHg if thrombolytic therapy is anticipated. Avoid routine BP lowering to prevent worsening outcomes. Malignant hypertension or myocardial ischemia: Consider lowering heart rate using β 1-adrenergic blockers (e.g., esmolol ). Prevention of Complications: Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT): Subcutaneous heparin (unfractionated or low-molecular-weight) Pneumatic compression stockings Cerebral Edema: Peak edema: 2nd-3rd day post-stroke. Mannitol and water restriction can raise serum osmolarity. Avoid hypovolemia Hemicraniectomy Neuroprotection: Fever is detrimental: Treat with antipyretics and surface cooling. Serum glucose management: Keep levels <10.0 mmol/L (180 mg/dL) and >3.3 mmol/L (60 mg/dL). Intravenous Thrombolysis: IV rtPA (Alteplase) within 3 hours (0.9 mg/kg, max 90 mg, 10% bolus, rest over 60 minutes) is effective despite a 6.4% risk of intracranial hemorrhage. Extended window: 3-4.5 hours (limited efficacy) per ECASS III trial. Tenecteplase (0.25 mg/kg IV bolus) is also used, with simpler administration. Endovascular Revascularization: For large-vessel occlusions (MCA, ICA, basilar artery), mechanical thrombectomy improves outcomes, especially within 6 hours. Antithrombotic Treatment: Aspirin (160-300 mg daily) within 48 hours reduces stroke recurrence. Anticoagulation (heparin, oral anticoagulants) is not recommended for atherothrombotic strokes but may benefit dural sinus thrombosis . Cerebellar Stroke Management: Watch for signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) , which can cause brainstem compression. Suboccipital decompression is recommended before brainstem compression in deteriorating patients. Rehabilitation and Stroke Units: Early physical, occupational, and speech therapy . Use of pneumatic compression stockings to prevent DVT. Constrained movement therapy for hemiparesis, even years post-stroke. Controversial role of SSRIs in motor recovery but helpful in preventing poststroke depression.

questions.question: A 65-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that resolved completely within 2 hours. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg. Based on his ABCD2 score of 6, what is the most appropriate immediate management?

options.A: Start oral aspirin 81 mg daily alone

questions.explanation: aspirin alone in preventing recurrent stroke after TIA. This regimen reduces 90-day stroke risk from 11.7% to 8.2% without significant increase in major hemorrhage Initial loading dose of clopidogrel 300 mg followed by 75 mg daily with aspirin 75 mg is the recommended protocol ABCD2 score helps stratify TIA patients' risk of stroke: Age ≥ 60 years (1 point) BP ≥ 140/90 (1 point) Clinical features (weakness=2, speech disturbance=1) Duration ( ≥ 60 min=2, 10-59 min=1) Diabetes (1 point) High ABCD2 score ( ≥ 4) indicates high risk of early recurrent stroke: Early aggressive antiplatelet therapy with DAPT (first 21-90 days) followed by monotherapy is the current standard of care for high-risk TIA patients Choice of long-term antiplatelet agent (after initial DAPT period) depends on individual patient factors and can include aspirin, clopidogrel, or aspirin-dipyridamole combination. Aspirin alone (Option A): While aspirin is effective for long-term secondary prevention, using it alone in the acute phase after high-risk TIA (ABCD2 score ≥ 4) provides suboptimal protection Warfarin (Option C): Anticoagulation with warfarin is not indicated for non-cardioembolic TIAs . It is primarily used for cardioembolic stroke prevention in conditions like atrial fibrillation Has higher bleeding risk compared to antiplatelet therapy. Ticagrelor alone (Option D): While ticagrelor has been studied in stroke prevention, it's not recommended as monotherapy. Recent studies show benefit only when combined with aspirin, similar to clopidogrel-aspirin combination. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 3345, 3346

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided facial weakness and slurred speech that completely resolved within 45 minutes. Which of the following statements about this transient ischemic attack (TIA) is incorrect?

options.A: If neurological symptoms begin improving within 1 hour, it indicates TIA
options.B: Treatment window period from symptom onset is 4.5 hours
options.C: Patient has highest risk of developing stroke after 72 hours
options.D: Symptoms must completely resolve within 24 hours to be classified as TIA

questions.explanation: of stroke is ~10-15% in the first 3 months, with most events occurring in the first 2 days. Transient Ischemic Attack: 1. Timeframes: Symptoms typically improve within 1 hour (Option A ruled out) Complete resolution within 24 hours (Option D ruled out) Highest stroke risk in first 48 hours Treatment window: 4.5 hours (Option B ruled out) 2. Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis primarily Normal Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) does not rule out TIA If infarction is seen on imaging, it's classified as stroke regardless of symptom duration 3. Symptoms (FAST criteria): F: Sudden onset Facial weakness A: Sudden onset of Arm weakness S: Speech deficit T: Time is neurons (better prognosis if symptoms are picked early) All symptoms occur irrespective of age group Symptoms are sudden in onset, not gradual Complete resolution should occur within 24 hours Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 3344

questions.question: A 58-year-old male presents with acute left-sided weakness. MRI imaging is performed showing: Which of the following best describes the significance of the diffusion-perfusion mismatch in this patient?

options.A: It represents chronic ischemic changes and is not clinically relevant
options.B: It indicates the ischemic penumbra and potentially salvageable tissue
options.C: It is a marker of hemorrhagic transformation risk
options.D: It represents a completed infarction that cannot be salvaged

questions.explanation: (penumbra) has decreased blood flow but preserved cellular integrity It identifies tissue that could potentially be saved with timely reperfusion therapy This mismatch is a critical imaging biomarker for selecting patients for intervention In the above scenario, Diffusion-weighted image (DWI) showing restricted diffusion in the right hemisphere Perfusion imaging showing a larger area of perfusion deficit The images show a significant mismatch between the DWI lesion and the perfusion deficit ischemic stroke MRI Q" data-author="László, János & Hortobagyi, Tibor. " data-hash="9340" data-license="" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure/fig4_323222772" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/gTSdo1a9AdlSw26FaDvE1744368553.png" /> MRI in Acute Stroke: DWI-Perfusion Mismatch: DWI shows areas of restricted diffusion (likely core infarct) Perfusion imaging shows

questions.question: A 72-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided hemiplegia and aphasia. His last known normal time was 5 hours ago. CT angiography reveals a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation: outside the 4.5-hour window for intravenous thrombolysis, but within the 6-hour window for mechanical thrombectomy . CT angiography has confirmed a large vessel occlusion (right MCA), which is an indication for mechanical thrombectomy. Mechanical Thrombectomy: 1. Need for Mechanical Thrombus Removal: Some clots, especially platelet-rich ones, are resistant to thrombolysis due to high concentrations of PAI-1. Mechanical thrombectomy can quickly restore cerebral blood flow in cases where thrombolysis is contraindicated, has failed, or the patient presents outside the thrombolysis window. 2. Goal of Mechanical Clot Manipulation: To rapidly restore cerebral blood flow in the affected arterial territory. To achieve functional recovery with reduced or no use of fibrinolytics. 3. Indications: Large vessel occlusion (e.g., internal carotid artery, M1 segment of MCA) confirmed by imaging. Within 6 hours of symptom onset for anterior circulation strokes. Can be extended up to 24 hours in selected patients with favorable imaging (e.g., good collaterals on CT or MR perfusion). Failed or contraindicated IV thrombolysis. 4. Procedure for Mechanical Thrombectomy: Vascular access via the femoral artery. A guidewire and microcatheter are advanced to the site of occlusion. A retrievable stent (often made of nitinol) is deployed to ensnare the clot. The stent with the entrapped clot is withdrawn under balloon protection to prevent distal embolization. Intravenous thrombolysis with tPA (Option A): This is incorrect because the patient is outside the 4.5-hour window for IV tPA administration. Antiplatelet therapy only (Option C): While antiplatelet therapy is part of secondary stroke prevention, it is not the most effective acute treatment for a large vessel occlusion within the time window for mechanical thrombectomy. Supportive care and observation (Option D): This is inadequate management for a patient with a large vessel occlusion who is within the time window for mechanical thrombectomy. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 3338

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset of vertigo, dysphagia, hoarseness, and left-sided facial numbness. On examination, he has left-sided Horner's syndrome, right-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, and left-sided cerebellar signs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Wallenberg syndrome . This condition is typically caused by occlusion of the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallenberg Syndrome): Involves the 5th, 9th, and 10th cranial nerves Vascular causes: Occlusion of vertebral artery Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) Superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries Ipsilateral symptoms: Facial sensory deficits (pain, numbness) Cerebellar signs (ataxia, falling towards lesion side) Vestibular symptoms (nystagmus, vertigo, nausea) Horner's syndrome Bulbar symptoms (dysphagia, hoarseness, palatal weakness) Loss of taste Arm/trunk/leg numbness Lower face weakness Contralateral symptoms: Impaired pain and temperature sensation in the body Parinaud syndrome (Option A): Stroke syndrome caused due to Pineal gland tumor- Pinealoma exerting pressure on superior colliculus. Upward gaze palsy - Sun setting sign. Medial Midbrain Syndrome (Weber Syndrome): (Option D) Involves the 3rd cranial nerve Presents with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia Dejerine syndrome (Medial Medullary Syndrome): (Option B) Involves the 12th cranial nerve Presents with ipsilateral hypoglossal nerve palsy, contralateral hemiplegia, and contralateral loss of proprioception 4 Brainstem Rules of Four: 4 Midline Structures (M's) - Motor tract, MLF, Medial Lemniscus, Motor CN nuclei → Medial = MOTOR 4 Side (Lateral) Structures (S's) - Sympathetic, Spinocerebellar, Spinothalamic, Sensory CN 5 → Side = SENSORY 4 CN in the Medulla, 4 CN in the Pons, 4 CN in the Midbrain 4 Motor Nuclei are divisible into 12 (3,4,6,12 = Motor, Medial) so (5,7,9,11 = Sensory, Side) 4 Medial Structures (Overall: OPPOSITE Motor weak, vibrate, proprioception + same INO) Motor Tract (Corticospinal) - Opposite weakness arm & leg Medial Lemniscus (Posterior Column) - Opposite vibration, proprioception arm & leg MLF (Median Longitudinal Fasciculus) - Same Look left (but right eye stays straight) or vice versa Motor CN Nuclei (divide into 12) - Midbrain (3,4) eye move, Pons (6) eye lateral, Medulla (12) tongue move 4 Side Structures (Overall: SAME Shaky leg, Horner's SRO, face sense + opposite pain/temp arm, leg) Sympathetic - Same Horner's SRO (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) Spinocerebellar - Same ataxia in arm & leg Spinothalamic - Opposite pain/temp in arm & leg Sensory CN 5 - Same face sensation

questions.question: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness affecting his face, arm, and leg without any speech disturbance. CT scan shows a small infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Which of the following vessels is most likely involved in this pathology?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Lenticulostriate arteries Explanation: The lenticulostriate arteries are penetrating branches arising from the M1 segment of the middle cerebral artery . They supply important deep structures including the internal capsule, putamen, and caudate nucleus. The described pure motor hemiparesis is a classic lacunar syndrome resulting from occlusion of a lenticulostriate artery affecting the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Lacunar strokes result from occlusion of small penetrating arteries and typically cause distinct clinical syndromes Lacunar Strokes Lacunar Syndrome Location of Infarct Supplying Vessel Clinical Features Pure Motor Hemiparesis Posterior limb of internal capsule or basis pontis Lenticulostriate arteries or paramedian pontine arteries Face, arm, and leg weakness on one side without sensory, visual, or cognitive deficits Pure Sensory Stroke Ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus Thalamogeniculate arteries Hemisensory loss affecting face, arm, and leg without motor weakness Ataxic Hemiparesis Posterior limb of internal capsule or basis pontis Lenticulostriate arteries or paramedian pontine arteries Ipsilateral ataxia with contralateral pyramidal signs Dysarthria-Clumsy Hand Pons or internal capsule (genu) Penetrating branches of basilar artery or lenticulostriate arteries Dysarthria and dyspraxia of hand without significant weakness M1 segment (Option A) : This is the proximal portion of the MCA before it branches; while it gives rise to the lenticulostriate arteries, occlusion here typically causes larger, more extensive strokes involving both deep and cortical areas. M2 segment (Option B) : This is the insular segment of the MCA that supplies parts of the lateral cortex. Infarcts here often involve cortical signs like aphasia or neglect, depending on the hemisphere. M3 segment (Option D) : This segment extends over the opercular surface and supplies more superficial cortical areas. Lesions here also typically present with cortical deficits. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine 21st Edition Page 3326, 3327, 3341
